results.title: The Koala brothers
results.creator_credit: Tobias Fouracre, Spellbound and Famous Flying Films
results.brief_description: Set in outback Australia, two aeroplane-pilot koala brothers set out to help anyone in need. Other Australian animal friends are also involved in their adventures. “The Koala Brothers” is a puppet-style animated television series suitable for children aged 2 to 6 years old. This DVD contains six episodes approximately 10 minutes each. Narrated by Jonathon ‘Jono’ Coleman.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Tobias Fouracre, Spellbound and Famous Flying Films

results.title: The Koala
results.creator_credit: Vincent O'Donnell, John Shaw, Anthony Buckley and Film Australia
results.brief_description: Prior to the 1920’s the koala was in danger of becoming extinct in Australia because it was unprotected. This film looks at the koala, its biological characteristics and the various types of species which are determined by its climatic region in Eastern Australia. Those features which make the koala particularly adaptable to its territorial environment are described and its life cycle is surveyed. Photography by Dean Semler.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Vincent O’Donnell, John Shaw, Anthony Buckley and Film Australia

results.title: The Knowledge of healing
results.creator_credit: Franz Reichle, Marcel Hoehn and T&C Film AG
results.brief_description: The Knowledge of Healing is the first feature length documentary dealing with Tibetan medicine. Originally recorded in Gyushi, “The Knowledge of Healing” is a medical manual written in the 12th century. Its text describes one of the most highly developed, holistic approaches to medicine, comprising its own pharmacopoeia of herbs, roots and minerals. The film explains the text through case studies of patients progressing under treatment for ailments and conditions deemed incurable in the West. The film also contains interviews with two leading Tibetan physicians as well as H.H. The Dalai Lama. In Tibetan, Russian, German and Buryat with English subtitles.

results.title: The Knock at the door
results.creator_credit: Helen Raw, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: War has followed Helen all her life. As a young girl, she wrote letters to her brothers overseas and she had feared losing her husband in the Vietnam war. That dreaded knock on the door was something she never wanted to hear.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Helen Raw, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI

results.title: The Kite
results.creator_credit: Animation and Interactive Media (AIM) RMIT and Ami Chew
results.brief_description: A fascinating animated work which uses string and buttons and other materials to create a sympathetic and likable character whose dream is to free a kite caught up in a tree on the top of a hill.

results.title: The Kiss
results.brief_description: Sue and Bob haven’t had sex in ages, much to the chagrin of Sue (Zoe Carides), but not Bob (Peter Brown), who would rather spend time fixing the car. Bob gets more than he bargained for when his gay, next door neighbour (Hugo Weaving) offers to assist in the car’s repair. (Awards: Winner Best Comedy and Best Score, TropFest Film Festival, 1998)

results.title: The Kiss
results.brief_description: Greta Garbo plays a woman accused of adultery and the murder of her husband. Set with a pre-talkies soundtrack this early film of Garbo’s highlights early European conservatism and the impact of social scandal on a young woman determined to maintain her dignity and freedom to follow true love. This collector’s classic edition of the film also features Garbo career highlights including rare fashion show footage, screen-tests and the star’s arrival in the USA.

results.title: The Kingdom of Tonga
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Oceans of Dreams - Currents of Change Series”.
The last Pacific Kingdom, Tonga, has a unique history, social and political system. Tonga was the only Pacific nation not to be colonised. Its special relationship of friendship and protection by Britain gave way to complete independence in 1970. Today, Tonga is devoutly Christian, with strong traditional values and attitudes. It faces the problem of a rising population, decreasing supply of land and the changes which affect all Pacific nations. Tonga has countered some of the challenges by a policy of encouraging light industry and tourism. Its other safety valve is migration; an estimated 25 per cent of Tongans live abroad and the film examines this issue as well as portraying contemporary life in Tonga.
